an5.144:4.1: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāketa, in Tikaṇḍakī Wood.
an5.144:4.2: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants:
an5.144:5.1:
“Mendicants, a mendicant would do well to meditate from time to time perceiving the following:
  1. The repulsive in the unrepulsive,
an5.144:5.3: • the repulsive in both the unrepulsive and the repulsive, and
an5.144:5.4: • the unrepulsive in both the repulsive and the unrepulsive.
an5.144:5.5: • A mendicant would do well to meditate from time to time staying equanimous, mindful and aware, ignoring both the repulsive and the unrepulsive.
an5.144:6.1: For what reason should a mendicant meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive?
an5.144:6.2: ‘May greed not arise in me for things that arouse greed.’
an5.144:6.3: A mendicant should meditate perceiving the repulsive in the unrepulsive for this reason.
an5.144:7.1: For what reason should a mendicant meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in the repulsive?
an5.144:7.2: ‘May hate not arise in me for things that provoke hate.’ …
an5.144:8.1: For what reason should a mendicant meditate perceiving the repulsive in both the unrepulsive and the repulsive?
an5.144:8.2: ‘May greed not arise in me for things that arouse greed. May hate not arise in me for things that provoke hate.’ …
an5.144:9.1: For what reason should a mendicant meditate perceiving the unrepulsive in both the repulsive and the unrepulsive?
an5.144:9.2: ‘May hate not arise in me for things that provoke hate. May greed not arise in me for things that arouse greed.’ …
an5.144:10.1: For what reason should a mendicant meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware, ignoring both the repulsive and the unrepulsive?
an5.144:10.2: ‘May no greed for things that arouse greed, hate for things that provoke hate, or delusion for things that promote delusion arise in me in any way at all.’
an5.144:10.3: For this reason a mendicant should meditate staying equanimous, mindful and aware, ignoring both the repulsive and the unrepulsive.”
